frameDefinitions: This frame deals with a Healer treating and curing an Affliction (the injuries, disease, or pain) of the Patient, sometimes also mentioning the use of a particular Treatment or Medication.
An Intoxicant is ingested in order to achieve an altered state of consciousness.

These words describe the recovery or healing of a Patient from an Affliction without reference to the influence of any Treatment or Healer (see the Cure frame).  '' 'My injuries had not yet completely healed.'
In this frame an  Agent preserves a Patient in order to prevent it from decaying.
These are words referring to control by a Leader over a particular entity  or group (the Governed) or an Activity.
frameExamples: Isis then <t>cured</t> Re by reciting a spell.
My injuries had not yet completely <t>healed</t>.
Sebek em hat was a <t>Leader</t> of Priests. ca. 1780 BC
listRoleDefinitions: The  Healer, anyone who treats or cures the Patient, occurs as the External Argument of verbs:

This   is the sufferer of the injury, disease or pain and can occur as an NP Object in this frame. However, Patient may not be expressed as a separate Frame Element but frequently occurs as the possessor of the Affliction, an example of  role Conflation:  (See section on Conflation.)
The Frame Element Affliction is generally the NP Object of a verb, frequently incorporating the Patient as a possessor, as described above:
The role Treatment is used for treatments and means, distinguished by separate FEs in FN-1.
The injested, applied, injected, etc. substance designed to cure the Patient.
The <fen>Body_part</fen> is the specific area of the <fen>Patient</fen>'s body which is treated.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
The <fen>Intoxicant</fen> is ingested.
The    Patient may either be expressed as the External Argument or, as in Health.Cure, may occur as the possessor of the Affliction (an example of role conflation):
This role is the injury, pain or disease experienced by the Patient.  Affliction occurs either as an External Argument of verbs or as a PP Complement of nouns or verbs:
Where Body Part is expressed as a separate constituent (rather than in phrases such as <ment>the wound on Pat's arm</ment>), it occurs as an External Argument:
The time at which the recovery takes place.
The location where the recovery takes place.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person performing the intentional act that leads to the preservation.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the substance in which the <fen>Patient</fen> might be  submerged to be preserved.
The <fen>Patient</fen> is organic matter that undergoes the preservation.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> preserves the <fen>Patient</fen>.
The <fen>Place</fen> where the preserving occurs.

The <fen>Leader</fen> is the one who has the role of leading.  With verbs, and with predicate nominals linking an individual to a <fen>Role</fen>, the <fen>Leader</fen> is usually the External Argument:

The role played by the <fen>Leader</fen> in a given situation, often an official title; incorporated in most noun LUsin this frame. When expressed separately from the target, <fen>Role</fen> usually occurs in a PP Complement headed by <ment>as</ment>.
The entity whose actions or beliefs the <fen>Leader</fen> directs in the context of a joint activity or movement.  This entity can be a political body, a person, or a group of people.
The <fen>Leader</fen> directs the <fen>Activity</fen>.
<fen>Time</fen> refers to the point in time that the leadership took place.
The locale from which the <fen>Leader</fen> leads the <fen>Governed</fen> or the <fen>Activity</fen>.
listRoleExamples: Mr. Amber embalmed the woman in Turkey <fex>in 1922</fex>.
Mr. Amber embalmed the woman's body <fex>in Turkey</fex> in 1922.
The general led his troops into battle <fex>on June 22, 1883</fex>.
He ruled the west <fex>from his palace in Milan</fex>.
